way, to tell the story of his difficulties in providing himself with a new cassock, to supply the place of a very old one which was no longer wearable:

"My cassock was worn to tatters, and I was forced by necessity to seek out some means of providing myself with a new one. This was no easy task in a country without cloth merchants or tailors. Having no cloth of any kind at hand, and nobody but myself to make the cassock, even if I had the proper material to use in its construction, I was forced to adopt an expedient of an unusual kind. I found I had a supernumerary blanket. This I resolved to convert into material for my own cassock. I succeeded, not in the most artistic manner, I confess, in cutting it out into something of a cassock shape, but to add to my difficulties I had neither needle nor thread at my disposal. Fortunately I had a strong pin and some slender twine, and by such helps I was enabled to connect the different portions of the cassock firmly enough together. Finding that it had not the proper clerical hue, I resolved to dye it, and I used some of the wild berries that were growing in the woods, for that purpose. But instead of dying it black they dyed it purple, and I found myself unexpectedly clad as a bishop. The next day I had an immersion in the lake, and the dye being washed out, I found myself vested in a white cassock like the Pope."

In the correspondence of Father Fouquet, we find the following incident related, which we quote as a testimony to the extraordinary influence which Father Chirouze exercised over the minds and affections of the Indians of British Columbia. Acting in obedience to orders received from their Superiors, Fathers Chirouze and Fouquet set out upon an ex-
pedition to visit the tribes that inhabited the northern parts of British Columbia. After a sail of three days, they arrived, when night had fallen, close to the shore on the borders of which the tribe of the Penelakrest Indians were encamped. They then learnt from their guide that the chieftain of that tribe had been massacred, a week previous, by some pagan Indians of one of the northern tribes. As a consequence of this fatal assault upon their chieftain, the whole tribe was on the alert, prepared for a fresh attack from the same hostile quarter. Though Father Chirouze and his little party were certain of the near presence of a large body of Indians, yet all was silent as the grave; no stir was heard, and no sign was visible to indicate that anybody was nigh. All the while the little boat and its crew were being narrowly watched from the camp. The approaching party were taken for enemies, and preparations were made to fire upon them as soon as they landed. All doubt as to the presence of an encampment was removed from the mind of Father Chirouze and his companions, by the barking of dogs, which they heard coming from the spot where they supposed the camp to be. They were on the point of stepping ashore—one moment more, and a volley would have been discharged upon them. Instinctively Father Fouquet felt the danger, and cried "Chirouze, Chirouze," a name
which he knew was loved by the Indians. Presently he heard a friendly voice answering in words of joyful recognition. Without further delay the poor Indians cast down their muskets and rushed into the water, in their eagerness to meet and welcome the Fathers. They were loud in their expressions of delight at not having fired upon them.

"My finger was on the trigger, my Father," said a fine young Indian to Father Fouquet, "when I heard you cry out 'Chirouze, Chirouze.'"

In a later communication, Father Fouquet relates the circumstances of his journey to visit the Seeshelt tribe, and the part he had to take in the election of a new chieftain to that tribe. He travelled in the canoe of a brother of the late chieftain, whom he discovered to be a candidate for the vacant chieftainship. He was a good Christian and a kind-hearted Indian, but there was, nevertheless, a dash of ambition in his character, which made him covet very much the post of chieftain over his tribe.

A rival candidate was in the field in the person of his nephew, the son of the deceased chieftain. Father Fouquet found opinions almost evenly balanced between uncle and nephew; the latter seemed, however, to be the more popular of the two. Both parties were willing that Father Fouquet should act as umpire, but he saw strong reasons for refusing to exercise this office. Yet the longer the settling of
the question was delayed, the greater would be the opportunity afforded for the kindling of bad passions, and the creating perhaps of permanent disunion and animosity among different members of the tribe. Already hot words were being interchanged, and several indications were visible that an internecine strife of a dangerous character was brewing between the opposite parties. The morning of the election came. Mass was said, at which everybody in the tribe assisted; special prayers in which all joined were recited by Father Fouquet, to implore the light and guidance of the Holy Spirit for the deciding of the important question with which all were then pre-occupied. Several hours passed without any final determination being come to, and Father Fouquet was apprehensive of the worst results following from the struggle for power between uncle and nephew. At last, help for the wise and pacific adjustment of the case came from an unexpected quarter. In the midst of the dispute the wife of the senior candidate, the brother of the late chieftain, came forward and addressed an earnest and well-reasoned discourse to her husband, to urge him to renounce his claims to the chieftainship in favour of his nephew, that harmony and peace might thus be established in the tribe. Her words were applauded by the multitude, and had the desired effect upon her husband. Like another Judith, this
poor Indian squaw became the salvation of her people. It is needless to say that she was a sincere and pious Christian.

Father Fouquet installed the new chieftain with much solemnity. At his bidding, all the Indians of the tribe promised fealty to the newly-elected chieftain, and the latter lifting his hand to heaven, in a loud voice declared that he would be always faithful to the trust reposed in him, and that he would ever walk in the path of justice and truth.
CHAPTER XXIII.

Following in the missionary footsteps of Father Fouquet, we find ourselves in presence of an immense assemblage of Indians, composed of different tribes. The Temperance banner floating in the air proclaims the special character of the great gathering. The usual devotional exercises being performed, forty-seven chieftains, accompanied by crowds of Indians of their respective tribes, come forward to renew the pledge of total abstinence, which they have been faithfully observing hitherto. The great majority of the Catholic Indians of British Columbia are total abstainers. About this time the Oblate Missionaries in that country found themselves called upon to discharge an extraordinary ministry of Christian charity. Several tribes of Indians were expelled from California, in consequence of the prevalence of small-pox among them. They took refuge in British Columbia. Their arrival, carrying with them as they did the seeds of contagion, was likely to become the cause of the spreading of the terrible malady, of which they were
the bearers, among the tribes of British Columbia. The Oblate Missionaries, who were ever on the alert to preserve the tribes under their charge from dangers to body as well as to soul, undertook personally the work of vaccinating the whole multitude of the Indians under their care. There was no one else to perform this work of charity in their behalf but the Fathers. Monseigneur D'Herbomez states that in one year, fifteen thousand Indians were vaccinated by them. By this timely exercise of charitable skill and devotedness, the progress of the small-pox among the tribes was checked, and multitudes of lives no doubt saved.

Father Lejacq, an associate of Fathers Chirouze and Fouquet, makes mention, in his correspondence with his Superiors, of several striking missionary incidents, from which we select the following for insertion in our pages.

A child of a minor chieftain of the tribe of the Babines fell seriously ill. A sorcerer, who had long resisted all efforts made for his conversion, sought the father of the sick child, to obtain the latter's sanction to his performing certain incantations of his art over the little invalid. The chieftain refused at first to give his consent to the sorcerer's proposal, alleging his unwillingness to act against the prohibition of the priests and bishop. The sorcerer was greatly irritated at this refusal; he scornfully
laughed at the fears of the chieftain to act in opposition to the instructions of the missionaries. He further denounced Christianity in scoffing terms. He at the same time assured the father of the child that the life of the latter could be saved only by the process of incantation which he, the sorcerer, proposed. The misled chieftain yielded at last the consent demanded of him. The wretched sorcerer, being allowed to have his own way, decked himself out with the quills of owls and eagles, and besmeared himself with red paint, which was mixed up with the down of wild ducks. He then commenced to dance around the sick child's bed, to utter wild yells, invoking the demon, and to work his body into horrible contortions. He then flung himself heavily to the ground. For a considerable time he remained perfectly motionless. This circumstance excited no special attention on the part of the beholders, as they looked upon it as being one of the rites of his art. At last somebody attempted to raise him up. It was then found that he had been dead already for some hours. Meeting his death under such circumstances, and whilst in the very act of invoking the demon, was regarded by those who witnessed it, and heard of it, as a visible judgment of God. The death of the chieftain's child followed quickly that of the sorcerer. These two events taken together had a very salutary effect in
opening the eyes of many duped and deluded Indians to the wickedness and folly of sorcery. With the aid of such examples, Father Lejacq felt little difficulty in persuading that portion of the great Babine tribe, with which he was then in communication, to renounce from their hearts all practices of sorcery. Shortly after these occurrences he set out for Rocher-Déboulé, the head-quarters of the Babines. He was received with lively demonstrations of welcome by all the Indians who were then in the village. The great chieftain Telusa was absent, but his nephew Koularnet, who represented his uncle in his absence, gave hospitality, in the chieftain's lodge, to Father Lejacq. One day, shortly after the arrival of the Father, two young stalwart Indians of the pagan tribe of the Naaskas entered the village of the Babines, and hurried with rapid strides to the lodge of the great chieftain. Their faces were painted, and their hair, which was clustered in high tufts upon their heads, was ornamented with eagle plumes. On entering the lodge, they placed their guns beside them on the ground, and squatting on their heels, they remained silent for some moments according to savage etiquette. They then unfolded in the following terms the object of their mission. "We come," they said, "as delegates from our nation, to know whether it is to be peace or war between your tribe and ours. We wish to learn
what your dispositions are in our regard. Three hundred of our warriors, who are ready for battle, are encamped at a distance of a day's march. They have sent us to say, that if you wish to trade with us our merchandize is ready, but that if you wish to fight us our guns are also ready." Koularnet, on the part of his uncle, the great chieftain, answered, "Telusa is absent, but I hold his place, and in his name say to you that we wish for peace, and have no desire to quarrel with you. It is true we have some deaths to avenge, but the priest has spoken to us. You behold him here now at my side; we wish to follow his instructions, and bury all our animosities in forgetfulness, and become new men. We are willing to trade with you, and are ready to purchase your furs."

The delegates of the Naaskas then made presents to Koularnet, and the latter regaled them with a hospitable repast. They then took their departure. After the lapse of a few days, the Naaskas were seen to approach the village of the Babines in great numbers. They were hospitably received and entertained by the latter. The following day, at the invitation of Father Lejacq, the Indians of both tribes assembled to listen to a discourse from him. He spoke earnestly and at considerable length on the blessings of peace and Christian charity. Several marks of approbation on the part of his numerous hearers
accompanied his words. After some days had elapsed, Telusa and a large body of the Babines returned to the village. Kialar, the great chieftain of the Naaskas, had also arrived. A solemn council of peace was inaugurated the next day. On one side were ranged Telusa and his minor chieftains; opposite to him stood Kialar and the chief leaders of the Naaskas. The crowds of both tribes were grouped behind their respective leaders. Father Lejacq opened the proceedings of the council by an inaugural discourse. The chieftains followed with fitting speeches.

The whole proceedings were conducted with calm dignity and order. One discordant voice only disturbed the harmony that reigned on the occasion. From the midst of the crowd a young man cried out, "My brother has been assassinated by the Naaskas; when I shall have killed a Naaska on his tomb, I will sign the treaty of peace." After this occurrence a certain tumult prevailed for a time in the assembly. At last the young man yielding to the prevailing desire for peace, and to the exhortation of Father Lejacq, entered into better disposition, and declared his willingness to agree to the terms of the reconciliation which was being established between the two tribes. Father Lejacq drew up the treaty of peace, to which the chieftains put their signature by making a cross opposite their names,
which were written by Father Lejacq. The following three days were spent by Father Lejacq in the charitable work of vaccinating all the Indians assembled at Rocher-Déboulé, pagans as well as Christians. The day of Father Lejacq’s departure from Rocher-Déboulé had now arrived. Though he started on his journey at the early hour of three in the morning, everybody was on foot to bid him adieu. All manifested unaffected grief at his departure, and begged of him to name an early day for his visiting them again.

Early in July we find Father Lejacq engaged in missionary work, surrounded by several camps of Indians. The news arrived that a great abundance of salmon had appeared in the river. For ten years the salmon fishing, on which these people mainly depend for food, had been a failure. A deputation from the different camps waited upon Father Lejacq to know how he wished them to act on the occasion. “We desire very much to catch the salmon, but we desire still more to listen to your instructions. If you will consent to accompany us to the fishing, we promise to attend to your instructions in the intervals of our work; but if you prefer to remain here, we will stay with you and think no more about the salmon.” Father Lejacq was touched to tears by this display of self-sacrificing eagerness of these poor Indians to become instructed in the knowledge of
God, and of the means of serving and loving Him. "To-morrow," said Father Lejacq, in reply to their enquiry, "we will all go to the fishing. There you will catch your salmon, and I will speak to you of God."

There is no truth which the faithful missionary has greater need of keeping constantly before his mind, than the importance of labouring, not only for the multitude, but also for the *one* individual soul. He should be prepared, when the occasion demands it, to put forth all the resources of his zeal, to employ all the powers of his mind, to go to the full extent of all his capabilities of enduring the fatigues of long journeyings—the sufferings of long fastings—to brave dangers, and to face death itself, when one soul has to be saved; yea, even as though it were the salvation of ten thousand that had to be accomplished by him. The Saviour of the world, to gain one soul, undertook a long journey, which He pursued until He sank wearied and exhausted by Jacob's Well. All this He endured for the sake of that one soul that was to come to Him from out of Samaria. In working for multitudes, true zeal no doubt rejoices at the abundance of the harvest that falls beneath the sickle, but self-love may also find its gratification in working successfully for the many. If the *one* soul for which it fell to the missionary's lot to labour was that of a prince, or other grandee
of the earth, or of some possessor of great wealth or great influence, then again self-love might find an inlet into the heart, even as though the multitude were being laboured for. But when the missionary is called by duty to go in search of a perishing soul in a far wilderness, whither no applauding eye can follow him but that of God; when it is the soul of some poor dying Indian, whose distant lodge can be reached only at peril of life or limb that claims his aid, oh! then a chance is given him of doing a work of pure zeal, without any alloy or earthly admixture of motive.

We have been forcibly struck ourselves, whilst making the researches necessary for the compilation of the present volume, by the frequent instances we have discovered of Oblate Missionaries exposing themselves cheerfully to extreme hardships and long fasts and journeys, with the knowledge beforehand that their ministry could possibly be of benefit to not more than a very limited number of souls; perhaps to not more than one soul only. We introduce these remarks, *à propos* of a work of charitable zeal which Father Lejacq was called upon to perform when on his journey from Stellatishonie lack-water Creek. When approaching the place in his canoe, he perceived that signals were being made to him by three persons from one of the banks of the river. He found on enquiry that they wished
him to visit a sick Indian woman, who lay dying in a forest which they pointed out to him in the far distance. Having moored his canoe to the shore, he departed, taking with him one of the men who had accosted him, to act as his guide. They started at nine in the morning, and travelled for the greater part of the day up a steep mountain side. From the account given him of the state of the dying woman, he felt he should not lose any time in seeking to reach her; he consequently walked, or rather climbed, up the almost perpendicular flank of the high mountain, with as much quickness as the difficulties of his way would permit. The summit of the mountain was covered with a thick pine forest, which, to their dismay, they found to be on fire. Right in front stood out the blazing mountain, presenting a wide stretching barrier of flame, which effectually checked their further progress in a direct line. On either flank huge smoke clouds were massed. Advancing into the cloud of smoke, they found themselves buried in thick gloom. The guide lost his way for hours; they groped about in the darkness at the great risk of their lives, as many dangerous precipices were lying around them. At last they emerged from the smoke cloud, to discover that they had gone far out of their way. In the meantime, the dying young Indian woman was waiting anxiously for the arrival of the Black Robe. At
eleven at night Father Lejacq entered her hut. He found her in admirable dispositions. He instructed and baptised her. After her baptism, lifting her eyes to Heaven, she exclaimed, "Now I die contented, for my soul has been washed and made white." In the happiness of contemplating such a death scene, the heart of the missionary speedily forgot the fatigues of the journey he had to perform to reach the place of its accomplishment.

Father Lejacq, writing to Monseigneur D'Herbomez, speaks in the following terms of the Indians of the districts evangelized by him:

"These savages are divided into four distinct tribes—the Porteurs—the Babines—the Holsofens—and the Sikkenes. The country of the Porteurs embraces the Basin of the Frazer and its tributaries; the district of the Babines occupies the shores of Lake Babine and its environs; that of the Holsofens includes the Basin of the Skeena and of its tributaries; the regions occupied by the Sikkenes includes the Basin of the Peace River and its tributaries. Until these latter years, the officials of the Hudson Bay Company were the only white men known to these savages; but since the discovery of the mines in the Peace River districts, they have been brought into contact with the miners. This intercourse did not tend to benefit them, but they came much better out of the ordeal than I expected. I can safely say that, speaking in general, all the savages of the mission are well disposed, and have a real desire to become good Christians. The use of intoxicating drinks, gambling, jugglery, and other evil habits to which they had been addicted, have disappeared as it were by enchantment, under the influence of the preaching of the missionaries. Twelve camps have
erected chapels which have been solemnly blessed by the priest. Three other chapels are being constructed. When these are completed, then every camp will have its own chapel. Our Indians are faithful in saying their morning and night prayers in common, wherever they may happen to find themselves. When they happen to be near one of their little churches, morning and evening the bell is rung for all to assemble in prayer. All the white men that have held intercourse with them, with whom I have come into contact, have been loud in the praise of those poor savages. And what seemed to strike these white men most, was their strict honesty. They not only avoid stealing, but if they happen to find any stray article lost or left behind by a miner, they run after him and hand it to him."

These lines were penned seven years ago. Let us hope that the continued intercourse with the white races of America, and of the British Isles, has not since then caused the Christian spirit of these poor Indians to deteriorate.

From Father Marchall's report, dated 15th January, 1872, we glean the following items. On the 27th of the previous December he arrived, after a stormy voyage, on the coast of the district inhabited by the Shishel Indians. A loud detonation greeted his approach to the shore. Presently gleaming flashes lit up the lower slopes of the great mountains that stood in the background, and the echoes of discharge after discharge of musketry repeated themselves many times amidst the hills, whilst the arrival of the priest was being signalled from camp to camp. The effect was simple and sublime. But it was not
the exterior beauty and grandeur of the spectacle that riveted the attention of the devoted missionary as he left his canoe, and turned his steps towards the village of the Shishels. He was absorbed, as he tells us, in admiration of the religious sentiment which prompted such a display of affectionate reverence, on the part of the great tribe of the Shishels, towards the priest of God. As soon as he landed, he was surrounded by a large multitude of Indians. Everybody tried to shake hands with him and receive his blessing, but he had to withdraw very quickly from these demonstrations of respectful welcome. Duty called him to the death-bed of an aged woman, who was awaiting the blessing of the Black Robe, to depart in peace. The religion of the Shishels did not consist of outward display merely. Father Marchall bears testimony to their deep piety and sincere love of God. He was struck by their tender devotion to Jesus Christ in the Holy Eucharist. He found the practice existing among them of making daily spiritual visits to the Blessed Sacrament. This they sought to accomplish by forming the intention of adoring Jesus Christ in the Holy Eucharist, in the nearest church where the Blessed Sacrament was reserved, which was that of New Westminster. Owing to the long intervals occurring between the visits of the priest, they could not enjoy the privilege of having the Blessed Sacrament re-
served in their camp chapel. Their pious ingenuity, however, suggested to them the above means of practising devotion to the Holy Eucharist.

Monseigneur D'Herbomez had instituted a system of public penances for public sins; for instance, for violating the temperance pledge, getting drunk, or giving great scandal in any way. These penances were willingly accepted by the culprits, and had a very salutary deterring effect in preventing them from yielding to the sudden impulse of evil passion. They very often came of their own accord publicly to acknowledge their transgression, and to ask for a proportionate penance. A certain Indian, who shortly before the arrival of Father Marchall, had allowed himself to be carried away by an outburst of angry passion, under the influence of which he addressed some insulting words to another Indian, came publicly forward in the presence of the Father, to acknowledge his fault. Casting himself on his knees, he said in a loud voice before all present, "Henceforward I will watch better over my conduct; I will battle against my pride; I will be more humble, and I will never offend my God again." Another who had committed a serious offence, came forward before several persons to ask a penance from Father Marchall. He first knelt down and prayed silently for some moments; he then stood up and said to those around him, "Let no one be surprised
or troubled at the heavy penance I am to receive, I richly merit it; I unite my humiliation and sufferings with those of Jesus Christ on the Cross, and I accept without a murmur the penance which is to be imposed on me."

An American Protestant came one day to Father Marchall, to request that he might be received into the Catholic Church. On the Father's questioning him as to the motives which led him to make such a request, he informed him that his wife was an Indian of the Shishel tribe, and a devout Catholic. "Frequently," he said, "when she knelt to say her morning or night prayers, she used to ask me earnestly to join with her in her devotions. At last I had to acknowledge to her that I was quite ignorant of any form of prayer, as I had never been taught or learnt any. 'What!' she exclaimed in surprise at such an explanation on my part, 'you a white man! you who read the language of books, not to know how to speak to God! you to have no knowledge of the Great Chieftain who dwells on high!' These reproaches I felt were but too well merited, and they caused me seriously to reflect upon my state, and led me to the resolution of becoming a Catholic."

Whilst following the exercises of the mission which Father Marchall was then engaged in giving, his resolution was strengthened by witnessing the
edifying lives of those savages by whom he was surrounded, and who were also attending the mission.

Father Marchall also mentions another instance which will give us a further glimpse of the heroic character of the faith of the devout women of the Shishel tribe. A young woman of that tribe was asked in marriage by a white man, who acknowledged to her that he was not a Christian. She replied that it was needless for him ever to expect to obtain her consent to be wedded to one who was outside of the fold of Christianity, and that it would be too great a source of grief for her to think of being separated eternally in the next life from one whom she loved tenderly on earth. Struck by this noble language on the part of a poor savage, the young man, her suitor, felt that the faith that had inspired her with such sentiments, must be true and divine. After further serious reflection, he resolved to embrace that faith. Father Marchall concludes his account of the conversion of this young man with the following particulars: "I baptized him conditionally, and received him into the Church. That day he declared to me was the happiest in his life. He wrote to me, shortly after, a letter full of the best sentiments. He rejoiced in the happiness of being a Catholic, and asked me to send him some books which would afford him further instruction, and help to confirm him in his good resolutions."
This conversion was quite providential. In a few weeks after this young man had been received into the church, he took seriously ill, and died in the first fervour, peace, and holiness of his Catholicity.

Whilst some of the Oblate Missionaries in British Columbia were labouring in abundant harvest fields, where fruits of holiness were ripening to perfection, amongst tribes already thoroughly christianized, elsewhere the missionary ground was being broken with difficulty and under many discouragements. There were tribes that had been thrown by their position into early contact with the worst types of white men, Americans and Europeans. Before the teachings of the priest could reach them, they were already poisoned in mind and heart by a foreign paganism more detestable in the eyes of God than their own.

The letters written by the Fathers who are engaged in missionary work among those latter tribes, form a painful contrast with those from which we have been hitherto quoting in our notice of the missions of British Columbia. The true apostolic spirit, whilst it suggests suavity of utterance and gentleness of bearing as the ordinary accompaniments of the intercourse between pastor and flock, suggests also at certain times a holy anger in which there is no sin when the hardened of heart have to be aroused and awakened to full consciousness. We
find the same Fathers who with one class of Indians had recourse only to words of kindly exhortation, employing the severest terms which their sacred character would permit them to use, in denouncing vices to which certain half-pagan tribes were addicted. A particular tribe, which seemed irretrievably abandoned to the worst forms of intemperance, was visited by Father Fouquet. He set before them in vivid language the heinousness of their sin, and addressed to them telling reproaches that startled them into a sense of shame of their conduct. He finally succeeded in moving them to a true spirit of repentance. At the close of his discourse, all the chieftains of the tribe retired to hold council together. They then came forward to declare to the Father, in the name of their tribe, that they would thenceforward renounce the use of intoxicating drinks. They also requested him to use his influence to put a stop to the trade in such drinks, which a neighbouring pagan tribe was illicitly carrying on, and which was a great source of temptation to themselves. The Father had the consolation of learning, after a considerable time had elapsed, that the good resolutions and promises they had made were being faithfully observed by the tribe in question.

In January, 1853, the writer was on a visit at Marseilles to Monseigneur de Mazenod who related to him the following incident, which the holy
Founder said had been communicated to himself in a letter which he had then lately received from British Columbia.

An Oblate Missionary, Father Pandosy, undertook a journey through a great desert, accompanied by three Indians. The object of his journey was to procure, at a distant post, a supply of altar wine for the Holy Mass. The little party were on their return journey, when they were overtaken by a terrific snow storm. They were traversing a vast and gloomy forest at the time, and were still three days' journey distant from their home. Father Pandosy depended entirely on his companions, who acted as his guides, to be able to pursue his way back to his residence. The storm continuing to increase in fury, they resolved to bivouac on the spot where they then were, until the following morning. The next day, when Father Pandosy rose from his snow bed, the storm had lost little of its violence. On looking around, to his dismay he found himself abandoned by his guides. They had fled during the night, leaving him to his fate. Certain death seemed at the moment to stare him in the face. The snow which had fallen during the storm had obliterated every trace of a pathway, and there was nothing to indicate to him the direction he should follow to gain his home. Even if the snow had not fallen, he would still have deemed it to be
almost impossible for him to find his way without a guide. In these straits he had recourse to prayer. At that time there was much question of the definition of the dogma of the Immaculate Conception. Father Pandosy, remembering that he was an Oblate of Mary Immaculate, felt that, as such, he had a claim as Her own son upon Mary conceived without sin. He then knelt down and made an act of lively faith in the mystery of the Immaculate Conception. He concluded his prayer with these words: "O Mary, Mother of God, as a proof of the truth of thy Immaculate Conception, deliver me from my present danger." Having a fine melodious voice, he then sang out in the forest the hymn, "Ave maris stella," after which he prayed a little longer. He then rose up with the conviction that his prayer had been heard: It was so. To his admiration of God's goodness, and of the powerful intercession of the Blessed Virgin, he saw lying at his feet a pathway through the snow, where none existed when he knelt down to pray. It was there clearly marked out at his feet, as though some invisible hand had swept the deep snow carefully from its surface. That saving pathway failed him not for the three days of his journey through forest and prairie, up hill and down valley, until it conducted him to the known precincts of his home. He arrived safely at his destination, bearing on his willing shoulders the
hamper of altar wine, of which he had gone in search.

Curiously enough, when we were in the act of penning these lines, an old book fell into our hands which had been purchased lately by a friend at a book stall in Holborn, in which we find related by an English officer, in a letter written over a hundred years ago, a circumstance fully in keeping with the incident of which we have just spoken. The title of the book from which we are about to quote, is: "Travels Through the Interior Parts of America; in a Series of Letters, by an Officer. Printed by William Lane, in Leadenhall Street, in A.D. 1789." The dedication of the book, which is addressed by permission to the Earl of Harrington, is signed Thomas Anburey, the name of the author of the work. The tone and diction of the passage we are about to quote, show that the writer was not a Catholic, and that he had but little sympathy with Catholic teachings or practices.

. . . . . . "Montreal, 16th November, 1776.

"During my stay at Trois Rivieres, there came down from the Illinois, several Indians of that nation, with an interpreter. . . . Among the group I observed one who had hanging round his neck the image of the holy Virgin, with our Saviour in her arms, which I thought very singular, as he was of a nation esteemed extremely ferocious in their manner, and whom the French Missionaries could not convert; but upon my enquiring of the interpreter if he knew the reason, he gave me the following account: 'In,
some skirmish, when the Illinois were at war with the Canadians, this image had fallen into their hands, amongst other plunder. Sometime afterwards a missionary, of which the French had great numbers travelling through the interior parts of Canada, to cultivate friendship, and establish their religion among the Indians, by chance met this person, and observing the image, was very much astonished; the manner in which he took notice of it excited the curiosity of the poor savage, to know what it represented, when the missionary, who no doubt was pleased to have such an opportunity of displaying his religion, told him that it represented the Mother of his God, and that the Child she held in her arms represented God himself, who had made himself man for the salvation of the human species, and explaining to him the mystery of the Incarnation, assuring him that in all dangers the Christians addressed themselves to this holy Mother, who seldom failed to extricate them. The Indian listened with the utmost attention to this discourse, and went away. Being out a hunting, soon after this, just as he had discharged his piece at a deer, one of the Outagami Indians, whose nation was at variance with the Illinois, and who was lying in ambush, presented his piece at his head. In this situation he recollected what had been told him about the Mother of God, and invoked her protection. The Outagami endeavoured to discharge his piece, but missed; he cocked a second time, and the same thing happened five times successively. In the interim the Illinois had loaded his piece, and presented it to the Outagami, who chose rather to surrender than be shot. From that time the Illinois would never stir from his village without his safeguard. There can remain little doubt but this circumstance was the means of his conversion to Christianity and the Romish religion, for he has certainly embraced that persuasion, as I followed him to the great church, where, upon his entrance, after crossing himself with the holy water, he fell upon his knees, and seemed to worship with as much devotion as the most devout of the Canadians."
From this narrative we learn that God made use of the holy image of the Blessed Virgin and her Son for the instruction of the Illinois, that this poor savage, in a moment of great danger to his life, invoked her protection, and that his prayer was heard, and his life wonderfully preserved. Again, that through wearing the image of the Blessed Virgin and her Divine Child, and invoking her aid, he obtained the gift of faith, and became a devout Christian. The Illinois and the officer entered the great church of Montreal at the same time; the first fell upon his knees and worshipped, the latter stood erect and made his comments. By which of the two was God more glorified then? By which of the two is He being more glorified now, after a century and more has elapsed since then?

Before quitting British Columbia, we revisit en passant the fine town of New Westminster. We find an active work progressing there, of which the zealous Father Horris is the main-spring. The action of his self-multiplying zeal is felt in church, schools, convent, hospital, and prisons. A few miles outside New Westminster is the flourishing establishment of St. Mary's, which is a church especially set apart for the Indians. A large agricultural school is attached to this church. The devoted Brother Allen, aided by Brother Patrick, conduct a well-organized collegiate school in New Westminster.
Returning eastward upon our journey in spirit, which happily requires neither canoe, nor sledge, nor horse, nor steam-car to traverse distances, we leave the Rocky Mountains in our rear, and shape our swift course to a spot often mentioned already in these pages, Ile à la Crosse. We arrive on the Feast of Corpus Christi. An Indian procession of the Blessed Sacrament is being organized. Three triumphal arches are erected at appointed distances, under which the Eucharistic King is to be borne in solemn state. The tents and lodges of the Cree and Montagnais tribes stretch out into the far distance. Several large banners are floating in the air. The procession issues forth from the beautiful and ample church. It is composed of Indians and half-breeds. Men, women, and children all fall into rank, and move along reverently and devoutly, chanting the praises of the Blessed Sacrament. Their costumes are not such as meet the eye in the grand processions of European Catholic lands. There is a strange admixture of articles of attire on the shoulders of that moving crowd. The skins of wild animals, of the wolf, and bear, and badger, intermingle with patches woven in the looms of Yorkshire, and with shreds of the calicoes of Manchester. But look into their faces! There you behold worship. Through the dusky lines of those unaffected countenances you may see issuing forth, in luminous
evidence, rays of that living Eucharistic faith which burns and shines within their breasts. These simple children of woods and prairies are at this hour, by such display of Eucharistic belief and fervour, making compensation, under the eyes of God, for the checks and restraints raised, alas! in certain Catholic lands to such manifestations, as theirs, of Blessed Sacrament worship. As the ocean when encroached upon along one line of coast-way loses thereby nothing of its vastness, for it forms other beds for its displaced waters on the opposite shores, so with the ocean-tide of Eucharist worship; if in one place it is forced to recede before artificial barriers raised by the hand of man, to other coasts it hastens to pile up its undiminished waters upon higher shore lines. Thus the public chants of the Eucharistic homage, when hushed by human agency in one land, break forth elsewhere as the voice of many waters rising before the throne of the Sacramental King—the Lamb that was slain and is alive.

Such reflections we are forced to make as we assist, in spirit, with the Crees and Montaignais Indians in the procession of the Blessed Sacrament, on the Feast of Corpus Christi, 1876. The procession advanced over paths that were strewn with flowers, dropped by fingers of tiny Indian youths and maidens, along the shores of the beautiful lake that washes the mission grounds. It passes through
the Indian camp. At the door of many a tent knelt some aged, infirm and home-ridden worshipper, to receive the passing blessing of Him who still goes about doing good. At last the procession reached the level summit of a little hillock, which commanded an extended view of the Great Prairie, and where an "Altar of Repose" was erected, from which Benediction of the Blessed Sacrament was given to the kneeling multitude. Father Leggeard, who officiated on that occasion, could conceal with difficulty, as he tells us, his deep emotion as he contemplated the scene before him, and gazed upon that adoring crowd of fervent worshippers—poor children of the forest—and upon that vast prairie, extending into boundless space, and upon the mission church and house, casting their shadows across the calm waters of the great lake; and as he listened to holy hymns which were being sung to the praise of Jesus in the Blessed Sacrament, over plains that had resounded erst-while with wild beasts' howl, or with wild warrior's war-whoop; or with croaking chant of sorcerer, "May God," he exclaimed, "be ever thanked for this change, and for having employed our humble society of missionaries in teaching those poor savages to serve and love Him!"

Before we quit the diocese of Monseigneur Grandin on our return journey, we would call attention to a circumstance which proves the esteem in which
that devoted prelate is held by the public authorities of the Canadian Dominion. The circumstance to which we allude is, that the Government have given the name of "Grandin" to a large district in Saskatchewan, near Fort Carlton, out of respect for the venerable bishop who bears that name, and in testimony of the great services rendered by him to society in those parts, during his long years of missionary and episcopal labours there.

We now ask our readers to accompany us to Winnipeg, the capital of Manitoba. We should remind them that in 1870 the Red River regions were erected into a Province of the Canadian Dominion, and received the title of Manitoba. Winnipeg stands at the confluence of the Red River and Assiniboine River, and promises to become, at no distant date, a large and prosperous city. Here we meet again Father Lacombe, who, in the interim has completed his great literary work, the first Dictionary and Grammar of the Cree language ever composed. We find him at the head of a community of Oblate Missionaries. Four missionary outposts depend upon the centre establishment at Winnipeg—St. Charles's, which is ten miles from Winnipeg—St. Laurent's, which is situated on the borders of Lake Manitoba—St. Florent's, which is on the Lake Qu'Appele—and a missionary station which is located near a spot where important works in connection with the Great Pacific Railway are in
progress. The regions encircling Winnipeg, and those stretching from that point far away to the west, are capable, by cultivation, of becoming highly productive. Certain favoured spots in those regions open to the eye vistas of some of nature's loveliest and grandest scenery, though three-fourths of the north-west territory will ever remain as we described it, barren and desolate.

On the morning of September the 29th, 1877, there was an unusual stir in the streets of Winnipeg. The new city was in holiday garb. The Governor-General of Canada, Lord Dufferin, and Lady Dufferin, were being feted on that day in Winnipeg, on the occasion of their visit to that city. From the statesman-like, witty, and eloquent speech delivered on that occasion by Lord Dufferin, we purpose to make some extracts. They will serve to corroborate what we have already stated concerning the fertility of certain regions of Manitoba, and the great beauty of some localities there, and concerning also the vast distances that have to be traversed by those whom duty, as in the case of missionaries, obliges to penetrate into the interior, or to pass from limit to limit of that scarcely-known and almost boundless wilderness. Lord Dufferin describes a traveller coming from the Lake of the Woods on his way to Winnipeg. He says:

"For the last eighty miles of his voyage he will continue
his journey through a succession of land-locked channels, the beauty of whose scenery, while it resembles, certainly excels the far-famed Thousand Islands of the St. Lawrence. From this lacustrian paradise of sylvan beauty we are able at once to transfer our friend to the Winnipeg, a river whose existence, in the very heart of the continent, is in itself one of nature's most extraordinary miracles, so beautiful and varied are its rocky banks; its tufted islands, so broad, so deep, so fervid is the volume of its waters, the extent of their lake-like expansions, and the tremendous power of their rapids. At last let us suppose we have landed our traveller at the town of Winnipeg, the half-way house of the continent, the capital of the Prairie Province, and I trust the future 'umbilicus' of the Dominion.

"Having had so much of water, having now reached the home of the buffalo, like the extenuated Falstaff, he naturally 'babbles of green fields,' and careers in imagination over the primeval grasses of the prairie. Not at all. Escorted by Mr. Mayor and his town council, we take him down to your quay and ask him which he will ascend first, the Red River or the Assiniboine, the one five hundred miles long, the other four hundred and eighty, which so happily mingle their waters within your city limits. After having given him a preliminary canter up these respective rivers, we take him off to Lake Winnipeg, an inland sea three hundred miles long and upwards of sixty broad, during the navigation of which, for many a weary hour, he will find himself out of sight of land, and probably a good deal more sea-sick than ever he was on the Atlantic. At the northwest angle of Lake Winnipeg he hits upon the mouth of the Saskatchewan, the gateway and high road to the north-west, and the starting point to another fifteen hundred miles of navigable water, flowing nearly due east between its alluvial banks. Having now reached the Rocky Mountains, our 'ancient mariner,' for by this time he will be quite entitled to such an appellation, knowing that water cannot run up hill, feels
certain that his aquatic experiences are concluded. He was never more mistaken. We immediately launch him upon the Athabasca and Mackenzie rivers, and start him on a longer trip than any he has yet undertaken, the navigation of the Mackenzie alone exceeding two thousand five hundred miles. If he survives this last experience, we wind up his peregrinations by a concluding voyage of one thousand four hundred miles down the Frazer; or if he prefers it, the Thompson River to Victoria, in Vancouver, whence, having previously provided him with a return ticket for that purpose, he will probably prefer getting home via the Canadian Pacific. Now in this enumeration, those who are acquainted with the country are aware, for the sake of brevity, I have omitted thousands of miles of other lakes and rivers, which water various regions of the north-west, the Qu'Appelle River, the Belly River, Lake Manitoba, Lake Winnipegosis, Shoal Lake, &c., &c., along whose interminable banks I might have dragged, and finally exterminated, our way-worn guest.

"But in contemplating the vistas thus opened to our imagination, we must not forget that there ensues a corresponding expansion of our obligations. For instance, unless great care is taken, we shall find as we move westwards, that the exigencies of civilization may clash injuriously with the prejudices and traditional habits of our Indian fellow-subjects. Against this contingency it will be our most urgent and imperative duty to take timely precautions, by enabling the red man, not by any undue pressure, or hasty or ill-considered interferences, but by precept, example, and suasion, by gifts of cattle and other encouragements, to exchange the precarious life of a hunter for that of a pastoral, and eventually that of an agricultural people."

For a quarter of a century before Lord Dufferin gave this admirable counsel, the Oblate Missionaries
in the far north were engaged in carrying out the rules prescribed to them by their Founder, to be followed in the work of civilizing the Indian tribes among whom they were to labour. Upon these points there is a remarkable identity of view between the instructions given by Monseigneur de Mazenod to his missionaries, and the wise counsels addressed to his hearers by the Governor-General of Canada, on the occasion of his first visit to the capital of Manitoba.

Before Lord Dufferin’s arrival at Winnipeg, he had already visited the town of St. Boniface, where he was received by Archbishop Taché. In replying to the address presented to him by the Archbishop, Lord Dufferin spoke highly of the civilizing zeal of the Catholic clergy of Canada, and made special reference to the labours of the missionaries of the Red River. “Perhaps,” he said, “there is no country where the success of Catholic missionaries, in promoting the interests of civilization, has been more remarkable, or has struck deeper roots into the soil than here in Manitoba.” He further spoke of his happiness at meeting Archbishop Taché, for whom, he said, he entertained a lively friendship and a profound esteem, amidst the scenes of his Grace’s long and extraordinary labours.

About the same time, on the banks of the St. Lawrence, at the Indian town of Canghnawaga, the
great tribe of the Iriquois were assembled, accompanied by Father Burtin, to meet the Apostolic Delegate, the Bishop of Ardagh. Father Antoine, Provincial of the Oblates of Canada, who for nine years had exercised an Apostleship among that tribe, acted as interpreter on that interesting occasion. We may judge of the important work which is being carried on in the Oblate Churches of St. Pierre at Montreal, and St. Sauveur at Quebec, by the statement of one item. The average of the annual Communions in the former church is 75,000, and in the latter it is 85,000.

The Oblate Fathers at Lowell lately opened one of the finest churches in the United States.

We close our present volume with these lines, hoping, with God's blessing, to have an opportunity at some future day of publishing further accounts of the missionary labours of the Oblates of Mary Immaculate in other distant lands, and also in places nearer home. But the main drift of our future volume will be to complete our sketches of the life of the holy Founder, Monseigneur de Mazenod.
